awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: A Novel Method for Laminar Burning Speed Measurement at Ultra High-Pressures
awd_abstract_narration:
The next generation of advanced combustion devices will operate under ultra-high pressure conditions in order to improve the combustion efficiency and reduce emission of pollutants. However, at such extreme conditions, flame tends to become unstable and experimental measurement of fundamental properties becomes challenging. The principal aim of this project is to provide a detailed time- and space-resolved measurements of the ignition process at high pressures. In addition, the measurement methodologies and developed computational models will have a broad and valuable impact on combustion and plasma communities by enabling predictive capabilities for designing and optimizing advanced combustion devices operating under extreme conditions. The project will also encompass significant educational activities, including classroom and community engagement, integration of research into relevant courses, undergraduate research program, and an outreach program for K-12 students.

The main goal of this project is to develop a novel method to measure LBS in the ignition affected region using a spherically expanding flame under ultra-high pressures. The complication with this region is that, the kernel growth rate does not only depend on the chemical reaction but also on other terms such as energy discharge, as well as radiative and conductive energy losses. None of these terms has been adequately assessed, due to the generation of ionized gas (i.e., plasma). The proposed research will fill this broad knowledge gap via combined experimental and modeling studies focused in three specific aims: (1) using a well-defined and well-controlled high-pressure experimental configuration; (2) developing a self-consistent theoretical framework to explain the influence of energy discharge on the plasma formation and initial flame propagation; and (3) modifying an available high-fidelity direct numerical simulation (DNS) code to account for the evolution of the plasma kernel and the ignition process. On the experimental side, the project will utilize high-speed imaging of the plasma kernel propagation in conjunction with advanced laser diagnostics. The plasma properties will be calculated using statistical thermodynamics. This project, for the first time, aims to fundamentally understand the underlying physicochemical processes controlling the ultra-high pressure ignition in a high temporal and spatial resolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Result: 

A diagnostic model was developed to examine the early stages of non-adiabatic flame propagation, specifically to measure the speed of laminar flames. This model provides a quantitative analysis of the impact of both plasma and flame propagation during the ignition phase, as observed in experimental data ranging from 0.5 to 6mm. The plasma model accuracy was confirmed through detailed experimental data and advanced kinetic modeling. The model was used to measure pressures ranging from 1 to 20 atm where prior experimental literature is available for model output verification. Subsequently, the model was expanded to estimate pressures up to 50 atm for methane-air mixtures, which necessitates the use of the model for precise measurement.

 

Impact:

The established model offers a streamlined quantitative approach for the interpretation and measurement of flame during the initial stages of plasma development. The model, demonstrated during the grant period, extends the measurement of methane-air mixtures to 50 atm which observes primarily ignition affected data. Although the methodologies were validated using methane, the theory provides a general understanding of the plasma flame system and can be applied to a variety of fuels where a large radius is not available and conventional methods cannot be applied (i.e., significant buoyancy effects, significant instabilities, high pressure). This is often the case for clean energy fuels like ammonia or hydrogen, which exhibit strong buoyancy and cellularity (respectively) early in flame propagation. The developed measurement method paves the way for extending the measurement of challenging combustion scenarios for the design of future high-efficiency combustion devices.

 

Explanation/background: 

The model represents and energy balance of the early flame and ignition kernel. The measured early kernel can be considered a super position of both flame and ignition plasma contributions. Voltage and current measurements of the spark kernel can be used to find deposited thermal energy within the early kernel. This thermal energy is considered to expand via thermal conduction which eventually reaches the appropriate radius and temperature to achieve self-sustained flame. The non-adiabatic flame propagation can be determined through the thermodynamic energy balance allowing the kernel temperature to represent the volumetric mean. As the experiment progresses the early kernel relaxes into the adiabatic flame temperature and velocity.

Validation of the diagnostic model was considered through two means; First, numerical modeling of the plasma kernel (1D transport and kinetic) also predicting temperature mass and size of the ignition kernel produced nearly the same result as the simplified thermodynamic model. Second, measured temperatures and volumes of the early kernel show strong agreement with the model results. A sample of results are presented illustrating some experimental and modeling results.

 


Last Modified: 11/04/2023
Modified by: Omid Askari
